brief_summary.textblock:
This study is a pilot study to investigate whether intake of lean or fatty fish, or lean
      meat would affect parameters related to health in healthy non-obese adults, and will serve
      as basis for future calculation of group sizes in coming studies. Participants consumed
      750g/week of fillets of fish or meat for 8 weeks.

      Hypotheses:

        1. High intake of either lean or fatty fish would improve serum concentrations of lipids
           and inflammatory markers as well as improve glucose tolerance during the 4 week
           intervention period.

        2. High intake of lean meat would not affect the serum levels of lipids, inflammatory
           markers and glucose.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Study on the Possible Health Effects of Lean Fish, Fatty Fish and Lean Meat Intake in Non-obese Adults

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  adults

          -  non-obese

          -  healthy

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  diabetes

          -  diagnosed diseases of the intestine or cardiovacular system

intervention.description: Participants consumed 150g of lean fish, five times per week for 8 weeks
Participants consumed 150g of fatty fish, five times per week for 8 weeks
Participants consumed 150g of lean meat, five times per week for 8 weeks

primary_outcome.measure: Changes in metabolic parameters (lipids, glucose, inflammatory markers) measured in serum

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Investigator)
